titlestmt.titleproper: Inventory of the Institute for Humane Studies Miscellaneous Records
Institute for Humane Studies miscellaneous records
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Hoover Institution Archives Staff.

did.unittitle: Institute for Humane Studies miscellaneous records

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Use copies of all sound recordings in this collection are available for immediate access.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Institute for Humane Studies miscellaneous records, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1985.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Institute for Human Studies was established in 1961 in Menlo Park, California by Dr. F.A. Harper. As a former economics professor at Cornell University, Dr. Harper made it his goal to establish an institute whose primary mission would focus on, “research and education in the conviction that greater understanding of human affairs and freedom would foster peace, prosperity, and social harmony.” Since its 1985 relocation to Fairfax, Virginia the institute has been associated with George Mason University where it continues today in the goals established by Dr. Harper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Collection comprised of sound recordings of lectures by various economists and other speakers delivered at the Institute for Humane Studies, relating to laissez-faire economic and political theory; correspondence, memoranda and financial records, relating to production of the festschrift Toward Liberty (1971) in honor of the Austrian-American economist Ludwig von Mises, and to a visit to the United States by the Austrian economist Friedrich A. von Hayek in 1975.

did.unittitle: Sound recordings of lectures, interviews, discussions, and meetings
Economics as a Science of Choice,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series: Microscopic View of Freedom (Individual)
Alchian examines why people make the choices they do, illustrating his different points with a variety of scenarios.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Alchian argues that the individual is most free when it respects private property the most.

did.unittitle: A group discussion with Armen Alchian,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Several men discuss the implications of Alchian's theories on property and liberty.

did.unittitle: General Utility Approach to Case of Monopoly versus Competition,
Legal and Economic Analysis of Monopoly and Competition,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Alchian examines monopoly and competition, especially as it applies to labor unions and particularly the Teamsters.
The accessioned tape also includes a discussion with Morley of success of the federal government.

did.unittitle: Problems of Monopoly: Discrimination and Restrictions on Entry,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Alchian examines the barriers of entry that a monopoly creates using examples such as bankers, used-car dealers, insurance agents, and university football programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A talk on education, including school tuition, state support of education, and tenure.

did.unittitle: Herrell DeGraff lecture on technology in agriculture,
Herrell DeGraff lecture on agriculture and the Commodity Credit Corporation,
Herrell DeGraff lecture on agricultural economics,
Herrell DeGraff lecture on agricultural economics,
Aaron Director speech on monopoly as treated by the classical economists,
Aaron Director speech on the classical liberal school,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Director examines the classical liberal school (particularly Smith, Mill, and Hume) and its relevance to the contemporary world. Topics include the division of labor, self-interest, decentralization of government, voluntary exchange, government intervention, civil liberty, and the relationship of political and economic freedoms.

did.unittitle: Aaron Director speech on new conservatives,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Director speaks about the new conservatives. Critical of the group, he compares and contrasts them against the liberal school. He covers a variety of topics including, but by far not limited to: humanities and utilitarian education, materialism, agriculture and commerce, and their intellectual base of Marx.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Director speaks about monopolies, not monopoly price theory.

did.unittitle: Aaron Director speech on freedom of enterprise and monopoly,
Aaron Director speech on full employment policy.,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Director argues that the public policy of full employment is not a new concept; it is grounded in the idea of maximum output.

did.unittitle: Aaron Director speech on housing prices,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In this talk, Director discusses housing prices. He covers price controls, housing assistance, and zoning regulations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This recording sounds like a seminar Friedman had with a small audience, who regularly ask questions and for clarifications. The session has more of a feel of a workshop than a traditional lecture. The focus seems to be on wages and prices.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friedman speaks about exchange rates in international trade. He is critical of fixed rates, instead advocating flexible rates.

did.unittitle: Monopoly and the Role of the State,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friedman discusses monopoly, antitrust, competition, and things that restrict competition such as patents, tariffs, and building codes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Topics covered include: deposits, fractional reserve systems, the Federal Reserve, fixed exchange rates, gold, freedom of choice and monopoly. Throughout, Friedman and the others use a variety of goods to illustrate their point: bricks, Aspirin, paintings, hi-fi systems, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friedman looks at the role of government in education. He believes that the state does have a concern in education, but he believes it should be left at funding of but not administration of education. Central to his analysis is the neighborhood-effect, in the process comparing education requirements to safety requirements in automobiles. He advocates a voucher system, though not by that name. He looks at the implications of his system on racial segregation.

did.unittitle: Milton Friedman lecture on welfare considerations,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friedman speaks about several issues all tied to welfare considerations. Topics include, but are not limited to: public housing, medical care--with particular emphasis on the British experience and the AMA's prohibition of foreign-trained doctors, and minimum wage laws.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friedman analyzes the history of liberalism, from its roots in thinkers such as Adam Smith to his contemporary world where it is more commonly called libertarianism, a term Friedman dislikes due to its closeness to the word libertine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A discussion on the role of government with an emphasis on a liberal society.

did.unittitle: Role of Government in a Liberal Society,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friedman looks at the role of government in a free society. Topics include: means and ends, unanimity without homogeneity, proportional representation, neighborhood effects and regulation, paternalism over the insane and children, occupational licensing, and parks.
Among the audience is F.A. Hayek, who asks a question.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In this speech, Friedman concentrates on the stability of money. In the process, he looks at backing a currency with commodities, counterfeiting, the dollar during the Civil War, the Federal Reserve System, a history of American monetary policy particularly during the Great Depression, and the role of government in monetary policy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. Friedman examines discrimination against ethnic and racial minorities. He believes a liberal, free-market system is the most beneficial system to these groups. He explains how the situations where discrimination is most prevalent is also where the situations are the most monopolistic. Other topics include, but are not limited to: taste vs. discrimination, free vs. fair speech, and right-to-work laws.

did.unittitle: Distribution of Income and Welfare Actions of Government,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friedman speaks about the intersection of foreign aid, tariffs, developed countries, and underdeveloped countries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With a "random comments" structure, Friedman ponders if a free country is stable on the long term. He analyzes this question noting that the history of the world has shown that despotism has been the natural state of man. He focuses his attention on the development and rejection of liberalism in the United Kingdom.

did.unittitle: A group discussion with Milton Friedman,
Monopoly and the Social Responsiblity of Businessmen,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friedman speaks about monopolies, oligopoly, competition, labor unions, and cartels.

dao.title: Monopoly and the Social Responsiblity of Businessmen,

daodesc.p: Monopoly and the Social Responsiblity of Businessmen, 1968 June 27

did.unittitle: Friedrich A. von Hayek sound recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part of the June 1956 series of lectures, The Creative Powers of the Free Civilization

Hayek speaks about the use of coercion by the government and how this is different from coercion used by others. He argues that society institutes government to stop worse coercion by others. Saying coercion is not all the influence men can have on others, nor the state in which all choice is eliminated, he defines coercion as when a person makes it so that what he wants someone else to do is the least evil choice. Following, he spends much time explaining what is, what is not, and what leaves an opening for coercion. He believes law is a pre-condition of freedom. To him, coercion is objectionable because it is a form of destroying a mind; it does not allow a man to make proper choice. On how coercion by government differs from other coercions, he says the government usually acts with the threat of coercion, though he states taxation is a form of coercion. Hayek believes coercion is only justifiable to stop the harm of other persons than the coerced person; it cannot be used when the only people affected are the participants in an activity--Hayek uses the example of homosexuality. He finishes by mentioning John Stuart Mill.

Topics discussed during the following question-and-answer session include, among others, conscription, taxation, Hayek versus Mill, Nazism/fascism, changing definitions of coercion, and monopoly and collusion versus coercion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hayek speaks about how man's ignorance of various things prevents mankind from moving forward. Included, he looks at the individual and its relationship with civilization and culture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hayek speaks about progress of society, what it is, what it means, whether it is inevitable, what causes it, and the importance of freedom in the equation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hayek looks at how various thinkers and noted people have approached freedom, liberalism, and reason through the years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hayek speaks about compensation for work and its place in economic, political, and social systems.

did.unittitle: Evolution and Significance of Rule of Law,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hayek outlines the history of the rule of law from antiquity to the present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This talk is a continuation of his previous talk on the rule of law. This talk focuses more on what the rule of law is and its implications.

did.unittitle: The Decemberline of Socialism and the Rise of the Welfare State,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hayek delivers the first of a series of lectures on concrete dangers to a liberal society. He defines liberty as a state where state coercion is at a minimum. This lecture is an analysis of various experiments with socialism and the varying degrees of a welfare state throughout the West.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hayek looks at the relationship of the individual and society when it comes to those than cannot provide for themselves. Included, he looks at the possibly of requiring people to purchase insurance to provide for them in times of need. While he looks at similar programs throughout the West, he concentrates on the United States' program. He feels it is a highest problem that the program is seen as an account someone pays into and not as a welfare program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hayek recalls the history of taxation and the aims of various taxes through history.
The audio is of poor quality at the beginning.
There is a second program on the original tape, as if someone (poorly) recorded over a group discussion with the talk by Hayek.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Saying cities are what defines civilization from primitive cultures, Hayek looks at the role of government and society in defining city life. He argues that while private property rights are not the end-all decider of what one can do with land, the marketplace has been the most efficient allocator of resources--as opposed to central planning. He is harshly critical of rent control and housing cost ceilings. He also looks at government subsidized housing. He finished analyzing building regulations.

did.unittitle: Meeting of the Institute for Humane Studies featuring F. A. Hayek,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The first featured speaker is Lou Spadaro, the Institute's new president. His remarks are on "the why" of the Institute. He then introduces Professor Hayek.

Hayek provides moral arguments for defeating socialism. He begins by saying the goals of the Institute are his, and that they both work to supply people with ideas for two reasons: helping business people defend their property and persuade politicians, and they provide intellectuals with the truth. Following, he lays the background for the talk by reflecting on the philosophical background of economists and how that affects their work. Getting to the thesis of his talk, he argues that one needs to make both the economic and moral arguments to defeat socialism, that one cannot do so with either by itself. Hayek then concentrates his time on the moral arguments. Touching on many facets, one such argument is calling the term "social justice" to be meaningless, arguing to demand the concept of social justice is to demand the destruction of western society. He ends by commenting on young people's relationship with classical liberalism. A short question-and-answer session follows the talk.
Charles Koch functions as a master of ceremonies for the meeting and, with Ken Templeton, gives introductions.
A recording of this meeting is also found in the Hayek papers, Object ID 86002.7.

dao.title: Meeting of the Institute for Humane Studies featuring F. A. Hayek,

daodesc.p: Meeting of the Institute for Humane Studies featuring F. A. Hayek, 1977 June 10

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heaton recalls the living conditions, both stereotypical and real, of Medieval civilizations in Europe. He uses this to compare and contrast it with contemporary conditions, values, and appraisals of Medieval times.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heaton recalls the history of the Industrial Revolution.

did.unittitle: The Widening Range of Competitive Enterprise in the 19th Century,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A talk on the industrial revolution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p:
To Heaton, entrepreneurship encompasses
1. One-man, family, or partnership
2. Joint stock corporation
3. Public Enterprise
His discussion of capital focuses on its origin and accumulation.

did.unittitle: Competitive Features of Modern Enterprise During Last 150 Years,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heaton recalls the economic history of the West of the previous 150 years.

did.unittitle: Balance Sheet: A Look at Freedom and Competitive Enterprise, 30's-50's,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heaton speaks about the nationalization of industries in Great Britain and the United States in the first half of the 20th century.

did.unittitle: Lecture on Great Britain as the highest profile welfare state,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A talk on Great Britain as the highest profile welfare state. He notes that the prime beneficiary of this system is the middle class, not the poor who the system was designed to benefit.

did.unittitle: Lecture on location and productivity in manufacturing,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This talk is about the effect of location on manufacturers on productivity in Great Britain and what role the government should play in determining where businesses and factories are located.

did.unittitle: Lecture on the National Health Service of Great Britain,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This talk is on the National Health Service of Great Britain and who should pay for medical care in an ideal system.

did.unittitle: Lecture on health care in Great Britain,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jewkes delivers a lecture continuing the previous lecture's focus on health care in Great Britain. He uses this examination to then look at the health care system of the United States.

did.unittitle: Lecture on the nationalization of industries in Great Britain,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jewkes look at nationalization of industries in Great Britain and how this relates to the welfare state.

did.unittitle: First lecture on science and technology,
Second lecture on science and technology,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Antagonistically, Jewkes delivers a second lecture on science and technology. He argues that education in science and technology is not more important than education in "the humane studies." He goes on to argue how knowledge in such studies is more important than faster advancement through technology or science. He believes there is a danger in oversupply of scientists.

did.unittitle: Lecture on John Kenneth Galbraith and the book The Affluent Society,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jewkes provides his thoughts on John Kenneth Galbraith and the book The Affluent Society. He argues that the book is appealing to people because it assures people they can be both humane and wealthy, where the contemporary, conventional wisdom holds the two as mutually exclusive. Jewkes finds Galbraith's history atrocious before examining Galbraith's economic arguments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Leoni examines the various definitions of the word "freedom." He argues the semantic differences between ideologies and/or locations is a serious problem. He calls for economists and politicians to work toward ending this problem, though he notes (with a nod to Ludwig von Mises) some people often purposefully misuse words for their own benefit.

The text of the lecture was available from the Online Library of Liberty, http://oll.libertyfund.org/?option=com_staticxt&staticfile=show.php%3Ftitle=920&chapter=193186&layout=html&Itemid=27 as of 27 Aug 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The sound quality is terrible at the beginning and the end.

In this talk, Leoni looks at how the concept of constraint defines what freedom is. As with his lecture the previous day, he touches on semantics, but for the most part looks at the contrast between freedom and constraint and how this defines both. He argues that freedom and liberty are the same thing and that it is ridiculous to argue about a freedom from some other thing.

The text of the lecture was available from the Online Library of Liberty, http://oll.libertyfund.org/?option=com_staticxt&staticfile=show.php%3Ftitle=920&chapter=193188&layout=html&Itemid=27 as of 27 Aug 2012.

did.unittitle: Freedom and the Rule of Law,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Leoni examines the rule of law, how it is fundamentally an English-speaking world creation, and its application around the world.

The text of the lecture was available from The Online Library of Liberty, http://oll.libertyfund.org/?option=com_staticxt&staticfile=show.php%3Ftitle=920&chapter=193190&layout=html&Itemid=27 as of 27 Aug 2012.

did.unittitle: Freedom and Certainty of the Law,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The sound quality is terrible at the head of the program.

The text of the lecture was available from the Online Library of Liberty, http://oll.libertyfund.org/?option=com_staticxt&staticfile=show.php%3Ftitle=920&chapter=193192&layout=html&Itemid=27 as of 27 Aug 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The sound quality at the head of program is terrible.

The text of the lecture was available from the Online Library of Liberty, http://oll.libertyfund.org/?option=com_staticxt&staticfile=show.php%3Ftitle=920&chapter=193194&layout=html&Itemid=27 as of 27 Aug 2012.

did.unittitle: A group discussion with Bruno Leoni,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerns coercion, progressive taxation, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a discussion at the end about market and political aspects of stockholder voting and rights in the modern corporation.

The text of the lecture was available from the Online Library of Liberty, http://oll.libertyfund.org/?option=com_staticxt&staticfile=show.php%3Ftitle=920&chapter=193196&layout=html&Itemid=27 as of 27 Aug 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This lecture is about group decisions and individual choices.
The sound quality is suboptimal at times, with a high-pitched squeal audible.

The text of the lecture was available from the Online Library of Liberty, http://oll.libertyfund.org/?option=com_staticxt&staticfile=show.php%3Ftitle=920&chapter=193198&layout=html&Itemid=27 as of JS, 27 Aug 2012.

did.unittitle: Possibility of a Restoration of a Maximum Area of Free Individual Choice,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The text of the lecture was available from the Online Library of Liberty, http://oll.libertyfund.org/?option=com_staticxt&staticfile=show.php%3Ftitle=920&chapter=193200&layout=html&Itemid=27 as of 27 Aug 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bruno Leoni speaks about federalism in the United States.

daodesc.p: Current Ideas on Federalism, 1962 August 17
Law, Economy, and Individual Freedom, 1962 August 20

did.unittitle: Freedom and Its Connection with Particular Forms of Government,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley delivers the introductory lecture to the Sixth Institute on Freedom and Competitive Enterprise, held at Claremont Men's College (later known as Claremont McKenna College) in Claremont, California.

did.unittitle: A group discussion with Felix Morley,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Free Society and Federalism"

did.unittitle: Nature of Federal Form of Government,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley examines federalism in the American system. In the process, he compares it to other forms of government in other countries, other eras, and Indian tribes. Occasionally through the lecture, he references the lecture of John Jewkes earlier that day. He places some importance on noting that the American system is not a political democracy.

did.unittitle: Federal System (U.S.) of Divided and Septemberarated Power,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley lectures on the American federal system: of state governments, a national government, and the people's opinions thereon. One point he emphasizes is how misuse and abuse of words like national and federal have lead to a great deal of confusion in the country.

did.unittitle: Response to Changing Characteristics of a Society in Political Government,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley looks at how government systems, with the focus on the American system, change shape over time, through amendment or Constitutional interpretation by the judiciary. In the process, he thoroughly analyzes the response to the 14th amendment and its ratification process.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley looks at the political aspects of the welfare state and the permanence thereof.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley lectures on how the United States' government is revealed in its international relations. He does this in showing how America is susceptible to the service state.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley lectures on the factors operating to maintain the system of federalism despite centralizing tendencies and pressures. Included is an analysis of the voting process and Electoral College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley analyzes the importance of federalism as the nature of freedom.

did.unittitle: United States Economy Has Vested Interest in Preparation for War,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley is troubled by the increasing reliance of the United States economy on defense spending since the end of World War II. Because of this, he looks at the foreign and military polices of the country. An important crux of his argument is the amount of democracy in a country's political system and its effectiveness.

daodesc.p: The Theory of Government, 1962 August 14
The Practice of Government, 1962 August 16

did.unittitle: The Monetary Mechanism and the Keynesian Theory,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Parable of the diner today

did.unittitle: Forty Years of Monetary Experience in Europe,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The very beginning of the talk is unavailable on the tape and thus on the digital file.

did.unittitle: Correlation of Unemployment to Wage and Price Mechanism,
European Community of Steel and Coal,
View of a World Without Economic Intervention,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rueff lectures on prices and the price system with liberal and socialist/communist economic systems.

did.unittitle: How to Influence Those Who Don't Agree With Us,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A talk on the Marxist theory of surplus value

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wright speaks about the strengths and weaknesses the West and the communists possess in economic, social, moral, morale, and military matters.
The sound quality is poor due to the tape's paper base.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A discussion on Marxim, socialism, and capitalism.

did.unittitle: German Economy vs. British Economy: A Comparison of the Post-War Rates of Recovery,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wright examines why the German economy grew faster than the British economy following World War II, when both countries were devastated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A talk about socialist and communist societies and how liberals can successfully engage, debate, and refute the socialist and communist ideas.

As a follow up to Wright's claim in the lecture that universities ought to be able to show how many faculty members can provide the pro-capitalist/anti-communist arguments, Wright and Milton Friedman debate the makeup of university economic department faculties.

did.unittitle: Wage Theory: Role of Unions in the Free Society,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wright examines the effect of labor unions on wages, taking both a historical and a contemporary view. He believes union power is analogous to corporate power and that neither should be allowed to achieve too large a size.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wright speaks about capitalism, particularly the notion that capitalism and private property are the same thing. He goes on to compare and contrast the systems, such as, for one of many points, which system is most beneficial to artists.

daodesc.p: Distribution of Wealth and Income, 1962 August 21

did.unittitle: The Welfare State: National Health Services,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arhur Kemp looks at the health care systems of the United States and the United Kingdom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arhur Kemp speaks on the monetary policy of the United States, with both historical and contemporary considerations.

daodesc.p: Domestic Monetary Framework, 1962 June 29

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arhur Kemp speaks about liberalism--as embodied in F. A. Hayek--in the contemporary world, especially as it relates to conservatism--as embodied by Russell Kirk--and what Americans refer to as liberalism, a kind focused on welfare.

daodesc.p: Economic Systems: Isms and Schisms, 1962 August 01

did.unittitle: The Role of Government and That of the Market and discussion,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arhur Kemp discusses the proper role of government and market forces in society, touching on broad topics such as paternalism before looking at how his ideas apply to specific issues. He speaks broadly, but often cites examples from and for the United States.

did.unittitle: Arthur A. Ekirch, Jr., sound recordings,

daodesc.p: Foundations of American Foreign Policy, 1962 August 15

did.unittitle: Manifest Destiny and the American Mission,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arthur Ekirch looks at American foreign policy through its history. He begins looking at the concept of Manifest Destiny. He uses this as a springboard to examine the American Revolution's influence throughout the world and America's later foreign relations throughout the world.

dao.title: Manifest Destiny and the American Mission,

daodesc.p: Manifest Destiny and the American Mission, 1962 August 16

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arthur Ekirch looks at how the Progressive movement in the United States turned the country's foreign relations stance from isolationism to imperialism. Particular focus is placed on growing paternalism by the government in domestic affairs, President Roosevelt, Anglo-Saxon chauvinism/racism.

daodesc.p: From Isolation to Imperialism, 1962 August 17
Changing U.S. Military Institutions, 1962 August 20

did.unittitle: Significance of the First World War,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arthur Ekirch argues that American involvement in World War I was the climax of the Progressive Era and caused the backlash against Progressivism. Key figures in his narrative are Wilson, Dewey, Bourne, and Carver. He further shows how war results in centralization of power.

dao.title: Significance of the First World War,

daodesc.p: Significance of the First World War, 1962 August 21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this Arthur Ekirch talk is available, but is not a totally complete recording of the lecture.

daodesc.p: Peace and Isolationism Between Wars, 1962 August 22

did.unittitle: The Coming of World War II,

dao.title: The Coming of World War II,

daodesc.p: The Coming of World War II, 1962 August 23

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arthur Ekirch looks at the American experiences in war, particularly World War I and World War II, and the corresponding influence on economic freedom and civil liberties.

daodesc.p: Total War and Individual Freedom, 1962 August 24
The Cold War in Perspective, 1962 August 27

did.unittitle: Sandia lecture by Dr. William Mayer,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. Mayer speaks about a study of U.S. prisoners of war in Korea. He says the Koreans have developed, as much as possible, the ultimate weapon: brainwashing prisoners of war.

did.unittitle: H. W. Luhnow remarks about the Mayer film 'What Can I Do?',

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Speaking to the employees of the Volker Company, Luhnow comments on what Americans can do to re-instill the American spirit in themselves and resist communism. He calls for increased Christianity in America as part of this.

dao.title: H. W. Luhnow remarks about the Mayer film 'What Can I Do?',

daodesc.p: H. W. Luhnow remarks about the Mayer film 'What Can I Do?', 1961 December

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: James M. Rogers speech

daodesc.p: What Can I Do?, 1968 August 02

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Proofs of a Conspiracy" - A Seminar conducted by Stuart R. Crane, Ph.D.
Bob Jones, of the university of the same name, introduces Crane.

The program from the event lists the subjects of the talk as:
- Why the super-rich support socialism.
- The interlock between the super-rich and the left.
- How history is distorted by the educators and the news media.
- Why big business wants government controls.
- How the U.S. finances Communism.
- The Establishment's control of Communism.
- Why the federal government wants riots.
- Why the Black Nationalists and the New Left are really tools of the Establishment.
- Why Nixon continues LBJ's policies.
- Why the Establishment must have no-win wars.

While this inventory matches the content of the talk, other paper materials included with the tape indicate the talk happened in Massachusetts. However, during the recording, Crane indicates that the event takes place in California.

daodesc.p: Proofs of a Conspiracy, 1969 November 01

did.unittitle: Interview with Professor W. H. Hutt,

Interview with Prof. W. H. Hutt by W. M. Evers III, H. G. Resch, Mark Venezia, Jonathan Kahn, and John Hagel on the evening of 13 July '71.

dao.title: Interview with Professor W. H. Hutt,

daodesc.p: Interview with Professor W. H. Hutt, 1971 July 14

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arthur Shenfield examines the ideas in F. A. Hayek's book The Road to Serfdom and how they apply to the world since publication of the book. He believes the world has not turned away from the road to serfdom directly, however, the book has indirectly influenced economic policy.

daodesc.p: Road to Serfdom + 30 Years, 1973 January 20

daodesc.p: Resources, Wealth, and Economic Growth, 1962 August 08

did.unittitle: Conservation and Utilization of Natural Resources,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Scott Gordon looks at natural resources from the economist's perspective. Topics include, but are not limited to, ephemeral resources; the economist's prefered usage level of renewable resources than those of, for example, fisherman; resource conservation as investment; resources as market competitors; food and farming economics.

dao.title: Conservation and Utilization of Natural Resources,

daodesc.p: Conservation and Utilization of Natural Resources, 1962 August 09

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This interview concerns the history of economic thought, Austrian school, South African conditions, etc.
